quoteFirst: Lieutenant Macdowell, second in command of Hodson's Horse--an eye-witness--says: "The steadiness with which the cavalry confronted this most anxious position for two hours is as deserving of praise as the courage of the infantry who carried the breaches.  At three a.m. we moved down in column of squadrons to the rear of our batteries, and waited there till
quoteLast: , when the enemy advanced from the Lahore gate with two troops of artillery, no end of cavalry, and a lot of infantry, apparently to our front.  I think that they intended to try and take their old position now that we had got theirs.

quoteFirst: They came in in detached, independent parties, and I found it impossible to time them, as some of them kept very late hours. I slept in the Simud Putih cave on this occasion, and found that next morning the bats returned
quoteLast: , and that the swifts went out an hour afterwards.

quoteFirst: _Monday, 14th._ Hard gales of wind. Brought to off Tortugas under our foresail, and
quoteLast: saw a sloop bearing down upon us. Got all things ready to receive her, fired our bow chaser, hoisted our jib & mainsail & gave chase, and, as we outsailed her, she was soon brought to. She proved to be a sloop from Philadelphia, bound to Jamaica; and as it blew a mere fret of wind from N.E.

quoteFirst: "Ay, ay, sir!"  I dutifully answered; and, moving aft to the skylight, raised the canvas cover which had been placed over it to mask the light of the low-turned lamp which was kept burning all night in the fore cabin, and glanced at the clock which, screwed to the coaming on one side of the tell-tale compass, balanced the barometer which, hung in gimbals, was suspended on the other side.  The clock marked the time as
quoteLast: , or within two minutes of two bells in the morning watch.

quoteFirst: We were out at rest in an open field on the Somme front when one morning,
quoteLast: , our cook, Alf, of Battersea, was preparing the company's breakfast. There was bacon, but no bread. I was standing beside the cooker soaking one of my biscuits in the fat.
title: 500 of the Best Cockney War Stories
author: Various; Hamilton, Ian, 1853-1947 [Contributor]; Thomas, Bert, 1883-1966 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: I know I tried to pray, begged the Lord to forgive my sins for His great name's sake, and asked for His protecting arm around me, and strength of mind and body to do my duty to my Queen and Country. I then retired for a little rest, until
quoteLast: , when our men were up, and then no more sleep. I wrote a number of letters that morning for poor fellows--some of whom were laid low before mid-day, and others struck down maimed, some to rise no more, long before sunset.

quoteFirst: "The whole affair was conducted with the utmost decency and decorum; there was the greatest gaiety, cheerfulness and complacency in every countenance. The ball was concluded
quoteLast: and the night was passed in the general satisfaction, without the least incivility offered or offence taken by any one, which is scarce to be said on the like occasions. We are told this was distinguished by the title of the Country Ball.

quoteFirst: The course of variation of temperature is somewhat different. The minimum temperature is attained in my green house at
quoteLast: in summer, and at about 7 a.m. in winter. The maximum temperature is reached at about 3 p.m. in summer, and about 1 p.m. in winter. The range of daily variation in summer may be taken to be from about 23° C. to 34° C.
